t: Job 34
Elihu Asserts God’s Justice
Then*p Elihu answered and said:
“Hear*pn my words, you wise men, and*ld give ear to me, you who know;
for*ln the ear tests words as*ld the palate tastes food.
Let*ln us choose what is right; let*ld us know among ourselves what is good.
For*ln Job has said, ‘I am in the right, and*ld God has taken away my right;
in*ln spite of my right I am counted a liar; my*ld wound is incurable, though I am without transgression.’
What*ln man is like Job, who*ld drinks up scoffing like water,
who*ln travels in company with evildoers and*ld walks with wicked men?
For*ln he has said, ‘It profits a man nothing that*ld he should take delight in God.’
“Therefore,*pn hear me, you men of understanding: far*ld be it from God that he should do wickedness, and*ld from the Almighty that he should do wrong.
For*ln according to the work of a man he will repay him, and*ld according to his ways he will make it befall him.
Of*ln a truth, God will not do wickedly, and*ld the Almighty will not pervert justice.
Who*ln gave him charge over the earth, and*ld who laid on him the whole world?
If*ln he should set his heart to it and*ld gather to himself his spirit and his breath,
all*ln flesh would perish together, and*ld man would return to dust.
“If*pn you have understanding, hear this; listen*ld to what I say.
Shall*ln one who hates justice govern? Will*ld you condemn him who is righteous and mighty,
who*ln says to a king, ‘Worthless one,’ and*ld to nobles, ‘Wicked man,’
who*ln shows no partiality to princes, nor*ld regards the rich more than the poor, for*ld they are all the work of his hands?
In*ln a moment they die; at*ld midnight the people are shaken and pass away, and*ld the mighty are taken away by no human hand.
“For*pn his eyes are on the ways of a man, and*ld he sees all his steps.
There*ln is no gloom or deep darkness where*ld evildoers may hide themselves.
For*ln God has no need to consider a man further, that*ld he should go before God in judgment.
He*ln shatters the mighty without investigation and*ld sets others in their place.
Thus,*ln knowing their works, he*ld overturns them in the night, and they are crushed.
He*ln strikes them for their wickedness in*ld a place for all to see,
because*ln they turned aside from following him and*ld had no regard for any of his ways,
so*ln that they caused the cry of the poor to come to him, and*ld he heard the cry of the afflicted—
When*ln he is quiet, who can condemn? When*ld he hides his face, who can behold him, whether*ld it be a nation or a man?—
that*ln a godless man should not reign, that*ld he should not ensnare the people.
“For*pn has anyone said to God, ‘I*ld have borne punishment; I will not offend any more;
teach*ln me what I do not see; if*ld I have done iniquity, I will do it no more’?
Will*ln he then make repayment to suit you, because*ld you reject it? For*ln you must choose, and not I; therefore*ld declare what you know.
Men*ln of understanding will say to me, and*ld the wise man who hears me will say:
‘Job*ln speaks without knowledge; his*ld words are without insight.’
Would*ln that Job were tried to the end, because*ld he answers like wicked men.
For*ln he adds rebellion to his sin; he*ld claps his hands among us and*ld multiplies his words against God.”
